author: fradamt
content: You're right I think, but I don't know how we can handle this nicely in the spec, other than with just describing the behavior in words

author: fradamt
content: Maybe with `on_proposer_slashing`, like we set `equivocating_indices` with `on_attester_slashing`?

author: fradamt
content: Are proposer slashings produced by any node, since they're trivial to detect, or just by slashers?

author: fradamt
content: In other words, if my node receives two blocks from the same proposer, would I immediately produce a `proposer_slashing`, which could then be processed and do what we need in the fork-choice of the node?

author: tersec
content: At least Nimbus doesn't detect proposer slashings

author: tersec
content: Slashing detection is almost purely altruistic anyway (no, not block inclusion, but finding the slashings themselves)

author: fradamt
content: Having nodes produce proposer slashings upon detecting an equivocation in gossip seems like one way to get this information to the fork-choice, but if people prefer to just have a note that says you shouldn't apply proposer boost when an equivocation has been detected we can also do that. Or not sure what other alternatives there are, the bottom line is that trustless payments are vulnerable without detecting proposer equivocation and having proposer boost conditional on that

author: fradamt
content: Or alternatively have a fork-choice handler for equivocation detection on gossip, e.g. `on_proposer_equivocation`, to be called when detecting a second beacon block over gossip? Just to actually integrate the behavior in the fork-choice spec, while keeping `proposer_slashing` out of this
